name: py-ml-dtypes

variants.name: build_system
variants.description: Build systems supported by the package

description:
A stand-alone implementation of several NumPy dtype extensions used in
machine learning libraries.

dependencies.name: py-numpy
dependencies.description: Fundamental package for array computing in Python.

dependencies.name: py-pip
dependencies.description: The PyPA recommended tool for installing Python packages.

dependencies.name: py-pybind11
dependencies.description:
pybind11 -- Seamless operability between C++11 and Python. pybind11 is a
lightweight header-only library that exposes C++ types in Python and
vice versa, mainly to create Python bindings of existing C++ code. Its
goals and syntax are similar to the excellent Boost.Python library by
David Abrahams: to minimize boilerplate code in traditional extension
modules by inferring type information using compile-time introspection.

dependencies.name: py-setuptools
dependencies.description:
A Python utility that aids in the process of downloading, building,
upgrading, installing, and uninstalling Python packages.

dependencies.name: python-venv
dependencies.description: A Spack managed Python virtual environment

dependent_to.name: py-keras
dependent_to.description:
Multi-backend Keras. Keras 3 is a new multi-backend implementation of
the Keras API, with support for TensorFlow, JAX, and PyTorch.

dependent_to.name: py-tensorflow
dependent_to.description: TensorFlow is an open source machine learning framework for everyone.

dependent_to.name: py-tensorstore
dependent_to.description: Read and write large, multi-dimensional arrays.

dependent_to.name: py-jax
dependent_to.description:
JAX is Autograd and XLA, brought together for high-performance machine
learning research. With its updated version of Autograd, JAX can
automatically differentiate native Python and NumPy functions. It can
differentiate through loops, branches, recursion, and closures, and it
can take derivatives of derivatives of derivatives. It supports reverse-
mode differentiation (a.k.a. backpropagation) via grad as well as
forward-mode differentiation, and the two can be composed arbitrarily to
any order.
